messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] kokuin (stamped seals)
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Blokes, Trickie, if the stamp was white hot it would simply be like a piece of plasticine when hit with a 10 kilo hammer!!!  A friend of mine has a
messages.messageBody:
Dear Blokes,

Trickie, if the stamp was white hot it would simply be like a piece of
plasticine when hit with a 10 kilo hammer!!! A friend of mine has a Naotane
wakizashi with a kokuin that reads in katakana "KOROMO", the town where
Naotane made the sword. This stamp has been struck slightly off true. I'm
not in metallurgy either, but I would speculate that when a hardened stamp
is placed against a tang resting on a very heavy anvil then struck very hard
with a 10 kilo hammer, that the softer tang metal truly flows like caramel
fudge - somewhat like the phenomenon of explosive plastic deformation. I
remember reading of a swordsmith in Japan who (in an interview) said that
metal can be pushed around from place to place. So all in all, considering
what little I do know of metallurgy I think it is done as I have outlined.

The Gassan with the stamp is more likely to be by Sadakazu 1st than
Sadakatsu. I have a monograph written by Benjamin Hazard of a Gassan I
tanto in the MMA that has a kokuin (from a failing memory...).

Regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, December 01, 2004 9:29 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] kokuin (stamped seals)



Not being involved in metallurgy at all, could not the stamp be white
hot and pressed into the nakago ?, keeping the 'hot area' to a minimum ?.

Rich

Ron Hartmann wrote:

> Matt, Rich, all -
>
> Yes, the Gassan did this thing, too. The few times I've looked at
> these stamps they really didn't look like they were "cold stamped."
> They don't appear "sharply" cut nor do they appear "pushed out" around
> their edges (so to speak). But I can't understand how you could "hot
> stamp" a nakago. It would seem the nakago would have to be at a "red"
> temperature for hot stamping, and that would seem to need to be done
> before the hamon treatment is done. These stamps seem to be nicely
> done and in keeping with the rest of a "finished" nakago, not done way
> ahead of finishing the nakago. Honestly, I have no knowledge of how
> this is done, other than what has been passed on over the decades. It
> would be interesting to hear from somebody (swordsmith?) who has
> first-hand experience on this. Let's see what others can offer...
>
> Ron
> STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] kokuin (stamped seals)
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, Rich, all - Yes, the Gassan did this thing, too. The few times I ve looked at these stamps they really didn t look like they were cold stamped. They
messages.messageBody:
Matt, Rich, all -

Yes, the Gassan did this thing, too. The few times I've looked at these stamps they really didn't look like they were "cold stamped." They don't appear "sharply" cut nor do they appear "pushed out" around their edges (so to speak). But I can't understand how you could "hot stamp" a nakago. It would seem the nakago would have to be at a "red" temperature for hot stamping, and that would seem to need to be done before the hamon treatment is done. These stamps seem to be nicely done and in keeping with the rest of a "finished" nakago, not done way ahead of finishing the nakago. Honestly, I have no knowledge of how this is done, other than what has been passed on over the decades. It would be interesting to hear from somebody (swordsmith?) who has first-hand experience on this. Let's see what others can offer...

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Matthew E. Hoyle
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, November 30, 2004 4:14 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] kokuin (stamped seals)


Ron, didn't the 20th century Gassan smiths do this as well? I was also
wondering how that was done.

Matt


----- Original Message -----
From: "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...>
To: "TOKEN" <token_kenkyu_kai@...>; "nihontostudy"
<nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>; <nihonto@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, November 30, 2004 9:56 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] kokuin (stamped seals)


>
> Hi all -
>
> Somebody asked me about how "kokuin" were put onto nakago. I've always
refered to these as "hot stamped" but really, I wonder how the smith applied
these stamps. The nakago being soft (not hardened), were they punched in
after the sword was finished? It would seem illogical to think the smith
"heated the nakago" enough to "hot stamp" their seal. Can anyone explain how
this was done?
>
> A related question is about Masahide who did apply a "kokuin" to his
nakago. Does anyone know if Masahide ever signed his nakago with his
"kokuin" only? (Not signing his full mei with it.)
>
> Ron
> STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihonto] kokuin (stamped seals)
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, is response to the Masahide question, I assume it is Suishinshi Masahide you are referring to, in Suishinshi Masahide to Sono Ichimon there are many
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron, is response to the Masahide question, I assume it is Suishinshi
Masahide you are referring to, in Suishinshi Masahide to Sono Ichimon
there are many oshigata of Masahide blades with the kokuin, none of the
kokuin on it's own though. There is a small section also on his kokuin
and Kao ( do you have the book ? ) it is in Japanese but I can copy that
section for you if you like.

Just for general interests sake, his Kao is made up up the disassembled
kanji 'Hide' which is re assembled in a different order, interesting.

cheers

Rich

messages.subject: kokuin (stamped seals)
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all - Somebody asked me about how kokuin were put onto nakago. I ve always refered to these as hot stamped but really, I wonder how the smith applied
messages.messageBody:
Hi all -

Somebody asked me about how "kokuin" were put onto nakago. I've always refered to these as "hot stamped" but really, I wonder how the smith applied these stamps. The nakago being soft (not hardened), were they punched in after the sword was finished? It would seem illogical to think the smith "heated the nakago" enough to "hot stamp" their seal. Can anyone explain how this was done?

A related question is about Masahide who did apply a "kokuin" to his nakago. Does anyone know if Masahide ever signed his nakago with his "kokuin" only? (Not signing his full mei with it.)

Ron
STL



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
